c74object.name: bach.classify
c74object.description: Arranges elements into classes, according to a custom equality test.

inlet.description: Result of the equality test: 1 if equal, 0 if not.

method.name: (doubleclick)
method.digest: Edit bell code for lambda attribute
method.description: Doubleclicking on the object forces a text editor to open up, where the bell code for the lambda attribute can be edited directly.

method.name: bang
method.description:
A bang in the first inlet causes the result of classification of the most recently received llll to be output.
N.B.: The object is not aware of changes you make in the lambda loop. If you change the lambda loop, you might want to re-input the most recent llll rather than just sending a bang.

method.name: forceread
method.digest: Read code from file even if incorrect
method.description: Loads a file containing bell code into the object, but ignore it if the code is invalid.

method.name: forcereadappend
method.digest: Read code from file and append it even if incorrect
method.description: Appends the contents of a file containing bell code to the code already owned by the object, keeping it even if it is invalid.

method.name: llll
method.description: In first inlet: Equal elements are grouped from the llll, and the resulting llll is output, having one more parenthesis level than the original one (corresponding to each group of equal elements, i.e. to each class). If a lambda loop is present, couples of elements are output from the 2nd and 3rd outlets. If the two elements should considered equal (and as a consequence one of the two should be removed from the llll) the equality test should return 1 to bach.classify's second inlet; otherwise, it should return 0. If a lambda loop is not present, the elements are tested for "standard" equality (as in bach.eq), according to the matchtype attribute.

method.name: read
method.description: Loads a file containing bell code into the object, keeping it even if it is invalid.

method.name: readappend
method.digest: Read code from file and append it
method.description: Appends the contents of a file containing bell code to the code already owned by the object, but ignore it if the code is invalid.

method.name: write
method.description: Writes the bell code into a file.

attribute.name: embed
attribute.description: When set to 1, the bell code for the lambda attribute is saved with the patcher, even if not set in the object box.

attribute.name: lambda
attribute.description: The lambda attribute allows setting a snipped of bell code to be called instead of the lambda loop. If the lambda attribute is set, the lambda loop will not be evaluated, and the provided code will be executed as well. For each lambda outlet of the object, an input pseudovariable is passed to the lambda loop, with their indices counted from left to right.

attribute.name: lambdaparams
attribute.description: The lambdaparams attribute allows setting the values of local variables to be passed to the bell code set by the lambda attribute. It is structured as an llll consisting of one or more sublists, each containing the name of a variable and its value to be passed to the code. For example, the llll [ $foo 1 ] [ $bar [ 2 3 ] ] will set the $foo and $bar local variables respectively to 1 and [ 2 3 ].

attribute.name: matchtype
attribute.description: When set to 0, numbers with different types but equal value (i.e. 1.5 and 3/2) are considered as equal. When set to 1, they are considered different.

attribute.name: maxtime
attribute.description: The maxtime attribute allows setting a maximum evaluation time in milliseconds for the bell code provided. If it is reached, the evaluation aborts and the code returns null. If maxtime is set to 0, there is no time limit. The default is 60000 ms (1 minute).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.
